description: A large nylon pouch, intended to hold a single 1-quart canteen, like those issued to the U.S. infantry.  Can also serve as an impromptu dump pouch.

//notes: the unfolded version
description: A nylon pouch, intended for collecting random items for sorting later.  It is currently folded, with no container capacity to speak of, and can only be attached to the webbing when unfolded.  Activate to unfold.
//flags: only the unfolded version is attacheable

description: A nylon pouch, intended for collecting random items for sorting later.  It is currently unfolded, ready to collect, and is taking up a fair bit of space.  Activate to fold back.

//notes: this pouch is highly-modular, with hook-and-loop inserts
the tourniquet pouch is supposed to be a separate item as well
for now, we pretend all pockets are directly attached and not removable
pockets are modelled after an image in source showing the pouch unfolded
description: A compact, folding nylon pouch for first aid items, such as bandages.  Two plastic inserts inside can hold a variety of different items, including pill bottles, secured in place by a cord.  There is a separate pocket for a tourniquet, hanging at the bottom of the pouch.

notes: height is assumed to be half of what the pouch is capable of, judging by the photos
there are supposed to be two of these inserts in the pouch

pocket_data.//max_item_length: allows items to slightly exceed size of insert
allows items to slightly exceed size of insert

notes: height is assumed to be half the height of pouch
there are supposed to be two of these inserts in the pouch
negative trim is to allow items to slightly exceed the boundries of the insert itself, like in source

pocket_data.//min_item_length: arbitrary value to disable items that are too short from being inserted into the pocket
pocket_data.//max_item_length: allows items to slightly exceed size of insert

description: A rectangular nylon pouch with a flap that opens to an internal container.  While intended to carry loose ammunition, it can be used as an impromptu dump pouch of a more general variety.

//notes: seems to work primarily as a leg strap or a shoulder strap, as per photos and manufacturer description
description: A large nylon pouch by High Speed Gear.  Designed to take in a variety of gas masks, in a pinch it can be used as an impromptu dump pouch.  This model is meant to be worn on either leg, attached to the belt.
//flags: replaced PALS_MEDIUM with BELT_GEAR_LARGE: this pouch has no PALS interface

//notes: seems to work primarily as a leg strap or a shoulder strap, as per photos and manufacturer description

name.str: MOLLE II gas mask leg pouch
name.str_pl: MOLLE II gas mask leg pouches

description: A large nylon pouch, produced by Eagle Industries as part of the MOLLE II set of soldier's equipment.  Designed to take in a variety of gas masks, in a pinch it can be used as an impromptu dump pouch.  This model can attach to PALS webbing.

notes: height is presumed thickness of two walls of the pouch

description: A tall nylon pouch for storing water bottles.  Takes in tall bottles up to 1.5L in capacity.
An open-top nylon pouch for storing 40mm grenades.  Could also be used to store other ammunition, like 37mm grenades, flashbangs, smoke grenades, and so on.
//weight: using weight of a similar product made roughly to the same blueprint

notes: negative trim added to account for slightly-larger items, like smoke grenades, which also fit in the same space

pocket_data.//max_item_length: added 10% to maximum length of a 40×53mm grenade to allow slightly-larger items, like smoke grenades, to also be stored here

//notes: this pouch is 'tall', and thus able to reliably hold extended-capacity box magazines
description: A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine.  When stored, standard-length magazines poke out of the top, where it's secured with an elastic band.  This pouch design makes it that much faster to use than a closed-top design with a flap.  Has PALS webbing on the front, fit for the same pouch or something smaller.

A nylon pouch fit for a single STANAG magazine and a single pistol magazine.  When stored, standard-length magazines poke out of the top.  Rifle magazines are secured with an elastic band, while pistol magazines are covered with a flap.  This design trades some quickness of use for covenience, since it allows you to carry magazines for both your rifle and your backup pistol in less space than two separate pouches would take.

//max_contains_weight: weight of an M1911 magazine: 0.156 lbs = 70.76 g ≈ 71 g
plus weight of 8 rounds of ball .45 ACP: 331 gr (= 21.448 g = 22 g) × 8 = 171.59 g ≈ 172 g
//max_contains_volume: might be able to fit in a slightly-larger magazine
pocket_data.//min_item_length: slightly shorter than length of pouch (3.65 in. ≈ 92 mm)
//max_item_length: 5.1 in., slightly longer than loaded M1911 mag

//flags: replaced PALS_MEDIUM with PALS_SMALL (aligns with other single-rifle-magazine pouches)

//notes: it appears as though the shell holder is not inherent to the pouch or is removable
photos of the pouch show a 5.56mm insert inside the pouch
we model the pouch as if the shell holder is inherent and the listed ammo are compatible with it in some fashion
description: A long nylon pouch, intended to hold up to 12 12-gauge shotgun shells, or ammunition of similar size.

notes: length is average height of patch, for pseudo-area calculations

//flags: replaced BELTED and OVERSIZE with CANT_WEAR

description: A small nylon pouch, intended for storing a single standard-issue hand grenade.  Can also fit a single grenade of slightly-larger volume.  Unlike most models on the market, this one is relatively quick to operate, because it uses a hook-and-loop strap, rather than a plastic buckle.
//weight: using weight of a similar product made roughly to the same blueprint
subtracting 5 g for the plastic buckle

notes: trim assumes the pouch is measured at farthest edges when filled
i.e., the inner pouch already has apple shape

pocket_data.//max_contains_weight: weight of M67 fragmentation grenade (400 g) + 10% extra
pocket_data.//max_contains_volume: volume of M67 fragmentation grenade (213 ml) + 10% extra
pocket_data.//max_item_length: longest side of M67 fragmentation grenade

//flags: replaced BELTED and OVERSIZE with CANT_WEAR

description: A skinny, skeletonized nylon pouch -- or, specifically, two orthogonal straps supported by elastic bands and a generous amount of threading.  Intended to hold a full-sized two-way radio for military communications, it can hold a single smaller item in its stead.

notes: large trim to account for the fact that this item is two pieces of thin cloth sewn together, with a lot of space in-between

pocket_data.//max_contains_weight: weight of Motorola SRX 2200 radio (10.9 oz) + brown battery (6.5 oz)
pocket_data.//min_item_volume: to prevent storing smaller items that may fall through the open corners of the pouch

//flags: replaced BELTED and OVERSIZE with CANT_WEAR

description: A nylon pouch with two compartments.  The smaller front compartment is designed to hold smaller smartphones or other digital devices.  The larger back compartment can hold something larger, like a small power bank; it also has two thin pouches for things like plastic cards.

pocket_data.//max_contains_weight: roughly the weight of an iPhone 13 (6.14 oz) + 50 g, rounded to the nearest 25

from visual dimensions of the flap pocket
from assumed dimensions of the back pocket
pocket_data.//max_contains_weight: rough estimate based on available dimensions

//max_contains_volume: from assumed dimensions of the back pocket's thin pouches
from assumed dimensions of the back pocket's thin pouches

//flags: replaced BELTED and OVERSIZE with CANT_WEAR

description: A small nylon pouch, intended to hold a compact field flashlight.

//min_item_volume: to prevent storing smaller items that would be hard to reach
half the volume of the pouch, minus another 5 ml to allow slightly-smaller items

//flags: replaced BELTED and OVERSIZE with CANT_WEAR

description: A set of sewn-together STANAG magazine pouches, in two rows of 3.  The front row is noticably shorter while allowing the same size of magazines in, thus being slightly quicker to use.  They each also feature small PALS webbing, though because the pouches are completely attached to one another at the front, the webbings can't be used as one long MOLLE panel.
//flags: replaced BELTED and OVERSIZE with CANT_WEAR
replaced PALS_SMALL with PALS_LARGE: takes up three slots

//notes: small straps on the side of pouches are not currently modelled

has an interior separator inside the main pocket, which it didn't seem wise to model, since there's no way to separate volume of main pocket from volume of separator 'pocket' without breaking something about pocket management for the player
unlike many other pouches, this one can be worn directly over the shoulder
description: A small nylon bag that has both MOLLE straps and a shoulder strap.  It can be worn over the shoulder, or it can be attached to a vest or a chest rig.  Best used on an expedition where you may not need a lot of ammo but would need food, drink, medication, or other short-term supplies.

from assumed dimensions of the back pocket's thin pouches
from assumed dimensions of the back pocket's thin pouches
from assumed dimensions of the back pocket

from eyeballed dimensions of the front pocket

//notes: there appears to be no 4-grenade pouches on the market or in US military equipment sets, so we're modelling it as a commercial-market double-grenade pouch
description: A pair of small nylon bags sewn together, each designed to hold a single standard-issue hand grenade.  Because each pouch uses a plastic buckle for holding itself closed, they're relatively slow to operate.
//longest_side: no longest side, since the pouch appears to be easily-foldable

//notes: while the pouch is open-top and is advertised as accepting 40-oz water bottles, we model it as though it only takes smaller bottles, as a way to differentiate it from larger counterparts
description: A nylon pouch for storing water bottles.  Takes in bottles up to 0.75L in capacity.
//weight: the source for weight gives conflicting information about the item's weight, listing both 84 g and 0.19 lbs ≈ 86 g
we err on the side of the heavier weight simply because it has a corresponding stated weight in US customary units
//material: has a tiny plastic cord lock at the top that's not worth considering as a separate material

//notes: the pouch is shown to be able to comfortably hold a 30-round MP5 magazine, but anything longer would likely sway too much to sit comfortably
description: A thin nylon pouch with a flexible retention cord.  Can store a single pistol magazine, including some of the extended ones.

notes: negative trim is to account for the extra parts (the cord etc.)

pocket_data.//max_contains_weight: large-enough to accomodate a full SMG magazine
pocket_data.//min_item_length: roughly half the length of the pouch

//sources: dimensions of a pair of handcuffs
description: A square nylon pouch with a flap.  Intended for holding chain handcuffs, to be worn by a sworn officer of the law.  Should also be able to store a bit of cordage.

//max_contains_volume: from dimensions of a pair of NIJ-compliant handcuffs

//notes: this pouch is restrictive in volume and length because of the flap
description: An older, faded nylon pouch with a snap button.  Can store a single pistol magazine, originally intended for the previously standard-issue M9 magazines.
//longest_side: no longest side, since the pouch appears to be easily-foldable

//notes: this pouch is slightly-less-restrictive in volume and length because of the Velcro flap, but is still restricted to medium-capacity pistol magazines
description: A thin nylon pouch with a hook-and-loop flap.  Can store a single pistol magazine.  Originally designed to hold magazines for M17, the standard-issue pistol in the U.S. Army before the Cataclysm.

notes: even though the pouch appears to be rigid, we model it as being able to fold depth-wise, for storage purposes

description: A nylon pouch, essentially a miniature dump pouch.  Can be used to store a small quantity of anything, including loose ammunition, batteries, matches, and anything else you might need in the field.

//notes: we model pocket dimensions after the M18 smoke grenade, since it's stated to fit inside the pouch and is much larger than the M84 stun grenade aka flashbang
description: A nylon pouch for storing a single flashbang grenade.  It is also large enough to fit a smoke grenade.
//longest_side: no longest side, since the pouch appears to be easily-foldable

pocket_data.//max_contains_weight: weight of M18 smoke grenade (539 g), rounded to the nearest 50/100 g
//max_contains_volume: volume of M18 smoke grenade, rounded to the nearest 50/100 ml
pocket_data.//max_item_length: longest side of M18 smoke grenade

description: A nylon pouch for storing a single SMG magazine.  Fits most regular and extended SMG magazines.

pocket_data.//max_contains_volume: just above the volume of MP5 40-round magazine

description: A nylon pouch for storing a single magazine in .308/7.62×51mm NATO caliber.  Fits magazines up to 30 rounds in capacity.
//longest_side: no longest side, since the pouch appears to be easily-foldable

description: A pair of nylon pouches for STANAG magazines, with straps to attach to the leg with.  Each pouch holds up to two 30-round STANAG magazines.

notes: negative trim to account for straps and buckles

//longest_side: no longest side, since the pouch appears to be easily-foldable

//notes: currently modelled as a single large pouch, irrespective of the pocket division
description: A large nylon pouch, with straps to wear on the leg with.  Intended to carry medical devices and emergency medicine, it can easily be used for miscellanea and extra storage.

//notes: description says it can also be worn on the shoulder with a removable strap
description: A large nylon pouch, with straps to wear on the leg with.  The cord lock mechanism can quickly secure a large inner compartment.
